utterances: And let's talk about this better-than-expected jobs report with NPR's Yuki Noguchi, is in our studios.
Hi, Yuki.
Good morning, Steve.
OK, so how good was it?
Well, there were 203,000 new jobs added to payroll this last month.
That's according to a survey of businesses and government.
There's another separate survey of households that show that 818,000 more people worked last month than the previous month.
That's an enormous monthly gain.
A lot of people went back to work because the government shutdown ended, of course.
But people were also simply able to get work, and that's why you saw the jobless rate decline from 7.3 percent to 7 percent.
And that is the lowest level it's been in exactly five years.
And three-tenths of a percent, I mean that's actually quite a lot of a drop for a single month.
That's true, yeah.
It's bigger than we've seen.
And let's be fair.
It may be adjusted again, we don't know.
But it seems to be going in the direction that would people would like it to be going.
But let's talk about the quality of the jobs that are being added.
What sorts of jobs have they been?
Well, they are tend to be the good, higher-paying jobs.
There were big gains in health care, manufacturing, professional business services.
Another indication that people are getting paid more is that average hourly earnings for all employees also rose.

Let's talk about another factor here, Yuki Noguchi, because sometimes when the unemployment rate goes down, it may not be that more people are going back to work, it may be that people are going out of the labor force, and so the percentage seems to improve but things aren't really improving.
Did that happen this time?
We've got 2138 coming(ph) heading to 2.0.
Polls show Macri leading Daniel Scioli, the candidate of the long-ruling Peronist party, in the run-up to Sunday's election.
Meanwhile, Macri's old team keeps winning.
Back at the bar, fans explode as Boca Juniors scores to win the national title.
For NPR News, I'm John Otis, Buenos Aires.
And now let's turn to the presidential campaign here in America, where the Latino vote will be significant.
Hillary Clinton rallied Latinos in San Antonio, Texas, yesterday, and NPR's Tamara Keith was there.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG)
(Singing in Spanish).
Folklorico dancers entertained the crowd of about 2,500 people waiting for Clinton to take the stage.
An accomplished young mariachi sang the national anthem.
(Singing) Star-spangled banner yet wave...
This wasn't just any Hillary Clinton campaign event.
This was a Latinos for Hillary event.
Brightly colored banners hung all around historic Sunset Station in San Antonio with the words La Hillary (speaking Spanish) -The Hillary, I Am with You.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
But I want you to know I am not just La Hillary.
I'm also tu Hillary.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHEERING)
Not just The Hillary, but your Hillary.
The San Antonio campaign stop was something of a homecoming for Clinton, who in 1972 spent three months in the city registering voters in support of the McGovern presidential campaign.
In 2008, she won the Texas primary, but ended up losing the delegate race.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
I owe the people of South Texas a lot.
You worked hard for me.
I'm running for president to work hard for you.
(APPLAUSE)
Clinton was in San Antonio to collect the endorsement of Julian Castro, a member of President Obama's cabinet and the popular former mayor of San Antonio.
He is a rising star in the Democratic Party, often talked about as a possible running mate for Clinton.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
In 2016, the Latino community is going to play a critical role in electing our next president.
And Clinton's campaign clearly sees Latinos as a key part of her coalition.
San Antonio's population is more than 60 percent Hispanic.
In many ways, this city is a window into America's future.
The primary in Texas is March 1, and once again, it will be a major prize.
Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders visited the state in July, holding two large rallies.
He now has two paid staff on the ground in Texas building an organization.
Clinton's campaign will, too, soon.
Christopher Davis (ph) from Austin was at the Clinton event, but he told me before it started, he was still trying to decide between the two.
If Hillary announces one of the Castro brothers as VP today, I'm definitely a Hillary supporter (laughter).
But right now, I'm in between Bernie Sanders, of course, and Hillary Clinton.
He says education is the most important issue for him in this campaign.
That was a common theme in interviews with people attending the event, including Lisa Martinez (ph).
Really just education is my main thing, just because I - as a single parent, I put myself through college.
So that's one of the major things for me, even though I already graduated.
It's just, you know, to help other people 'cause I know what it's like to be a single parent and not have a lot of resources to help yourself.
Martinez had been leaning towards Sanders, but then her nine-year-old daughter Mackenzie (ph) encouraged her to learn more about Clinton's ideas.
She kept on trying.
And I think she's a good role model, and she's my role model.
Mackenzie convinced her mom to drive three hours to get to the rally.
Tamara Keith, NPR News, San Antonio.
Pennsylvania is one of the key battlegrounds in this presidential campaign.
Republican Donald Trump is well behind in the polls there.
He recently told his supporters he believes there is no way he'll lose the state if the election is fair.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The only way they can beat it, in my opinion - and I mean this 100 percent - if in certain sections of the state they cheat.
Trump is asking his supporters to sign up to monitor polling places.
Democrat Hillary Clinton is asking her supporters to sign up to vote.
She did so in Philadelphia today.
NPR's Sarah McCammon was there.

Outside West Philadelphia High School, a flock of blue-shirted Hillary Clinton campaign workers were spread out around the entrance, passing out voter registration forms amid a crowd of several hundred mostly African-American supporters.
All registered to vote - awesome.
Just down the sidewalk, volunteer Carmenletta Shelton was collecting contact information the campaign can use for organizing and to remind voters to show up in November.
Because we need Hillary in there (laughter).
We don't want Trump.
Did you hear about what Trump said last week about going to certain places in Pennsylvania and monitoring polling sites?
I sure did.
What did you think?
That's just his way of saying - he want to say Hillary cheating, or he think that she's going to cheat.
And she don't have to cheat because we are not voting for him anyway.
Shelton noted that Philadelphia traditionally has been a Democratic stronghold.
She speculated that Trump is getting nervous about the prospect of losing Pennsylvania.
Because he's scared to back out after talking all that trash he talking.
He know he ain't going to win.
